awd_titl_txt: A Hybrid Brain-Computer Interface for Long-Term Use by Persons with Severe Motor Deficit: Towards Development of Personalized Algorithms
awd_abstract_narration:
The inability to communicate is a major consequence of severe motor disabilities such as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), also known as Lou Gehrig's disease. ALS is the most common adult-onset motor neuron disease. Within the past three decades, Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) technologies have emerged as an alternative communication channel for persons with neuromuscular disorders. However, these communication systems typically require adequate eye-gaze control, which is difficult for those lacking voluntary muscle control. In addition, most current BCIs are inadequate for long-term use due to significant day-to-day variation in performance. To address these shortcomings, this project will combine two technologies to monitor the electrical properties of the neurons and the blood flow near the neurons. This combined system will adapt as the disease progresses and improve communication for persons with ALS. If successful, the system may be generalized to other types of motor control loss, including minimally conscious and vegetative states. The technologies developed will be integrated into a university curriculum that educates undergraduate and graduate students about the field. Furthermore, this research will be broadly disseminated through k-12 curriculum design and will provide training opportunities for women and under-represented minorities. Outreach activities include workshops: "Personalized Algorithms in BCI Systems" and "Hybrid BCI for Bedside and Home Users," poster presentations to disseminate novel outcomes from this study among students and researchers and development of a K-12 curriculum, "Engineering the Brain," designed to promote BCI learning opportunities among middle school students.

The project focuses on designing Brain Computer Interfaces (BCIs) based on functional imaging of the human brain using a combination of two non-invasive techniques: electroencephalography (EEG-to measure electrical activity) and functional near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS-to measure hemodynamic activity).  Algorithms will be developed such that the system considers both the neuropsychological status and environmental factors and can be implemented for in-home, long-term care of people with no motor control.  The system will be tested on persons with ALS (amyotrophic lateral sclerosis), the most common adult-onset motor neuron disease.  The project's hypothesis is that the incorporation of hemodynamic activities into conventional EEG-based BCI permits superior learning from brain states, provides unique features of the user's intent, and allows potentially game-changing solutions to provide end-users with a new level of communication autonomy.  To test this hypothesis, the Research Plan is organized under two objectives.  The FIRST Objective is to explore the associations of BCI performance variations and design a multimodal augmented predictive platform to improve the robustness of the BCI systems for nonverbal patients who have residual motor ability to control their eye-gaze.  The two aims of the objective are to explore the associations of ALS-BCI performance variation with both functional brain changes in ALS and environmental noise and to establish a set of predictive electro-vascular features best representative of users' BCI performance, and accordingly correct for unrelated activities in future BCI experiments.  Expected objective outcomes include (i) longitudinal assessment of brain pattern changes, (ii) establishing a set of predictive electro-vascular features, (iii) optimizing subject-specific factors essential for successful BCI performance, (iv) employing appropriate correction strategies to minimize unwanted activities and (v) maximizing adaptability with users' needs and environmental factors while minimizing inter-subject variabilities.  The Second Objective is to develop an autonomous hybrid BCI for non-communicative persons without any residual motor control (preferably participants in the first objective who have progressed to the locked-in stage.)  The system developed will have seven Degrees of Freedom (DOF) that can produce seven different commands for an external device based on the users' ability to modulate their brain signals through motor imagery (5 tasks), mental arithmetic (1 task) and rest.  The expected objective outcome is the introduction of a hybrid BCI that (i) is fully autonomous-signal-based, (ii) employs personalized techniques to enhance system performance, (iii) has enhanced information transfer rates relative to single modal EEG and fNIRS and (iv) can be conveniently set up at users' bedsides for long-term use.

This project is jointly funded by the Disabilities and Rehabilitation Engineering (DARE) program and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching objective of this research endeavor was to address the intricate challenge of inter-session and inter-subject variabilities in brain-computer interface (BCI) performance. Such variabilities have impeded the development of robust BCI systems, capable of delivering sustained and dependable outcomes across diverse subjects over extended periods. This study was strategically structured around two core objectives: the first being the systematic exploration of the intricate relationships underlying BCI performance variations, coupled with the conceptualization and realization of a multifaceted augmented predictive platform. This platform aimed to enhance the stability and robustness of BCI systems, particularly catering to nonverbal patients with residual motor control for eye-gaze manipulation. The second objective was focused on the design and realization of an autonomous hybrid BCI system, targeting non-communicative patients.

To address our initial objective, we proceeded with a multi-step process. The initial phase involved identifying key non-motor factors, particularly cognitive attributes that contribute to the variability in performance. The aim here was to establish a foundation for compensatory strategies capable of adapting BCI systems for prolonged, consistent utilization. This endeavor led us to explore the diverse multimodal factors that underlie the variability in performance within the realm of electroencephalography (EEG)-based P3Speller—an extensively used BCI for communication. In the course of this investigation, we engaged a cohort of participants, including individuals with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and healthy controls. Our collective outcomes, from this part, unveiled that a preliminary cognitive screening coupled with resting-state recordings could effectively unravel factors that contribute to the variability observed in P3Speller performance. This understanding has promising implications, potentially extending toward the formulation of personalized correction methodologies for a long-term BCI use.

Given the limitations of traditional non-invasive BCIs relying on eye-gaze control, we introduced an innovative approach centered on a functional near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS)-EEG paradigm incorporating a novel visuo-mental mechanism. Unlike the prevalent eye-gaze dependent systems, this approach offers enhanced communication efficiency for individuals with severe motor impairments, particularly those in a locked-in state. Our paradigm's efficacy was demonstrated to surpass that of conventional BCI systems, most notably the P3Speller. Our investigation further delved into the identification of biomarkers linked to the performance. As a result of our rigorous research, we unveiled numerous neuromarkers that exhibited substantial differences between ALS and control group. These markers spanned various domains, including markers of electrical and hemodynamic responses, connectivity profiles, and topological metrics.

In our subsequent endeavor, our focus pivoted towards the development and assessment of an innovative, personalized fNIRS-EEG based BCI framework aimed to identify markers embedded within each subject's internal cognitive state, which in turn affect their proficiency in task execution. Building upon the foundation of our previously developed hybrid visuo-mental (VM) BCI paradigm, we proposed an innovative multimodal experimental scheme commenced with a quick pre-screening phase for every participant, which occurred prior to the primary BCI tasks. The gathered features from this pre-screening phase were then utilized to construct predictive models and correction strategies to achieve the highest performance for each participant.

Progressing towards the achievement of building an autonomous hybrid BCI system for non-communicative individuals, we introduced a robust framework for classifying integrated EEG-fNIRS data at the feature level. This framework hinged on a feature selection method driven by mutual information, strategically accounting for the complementary nature of the features. Our outcomes revealed a substantial enhancement in hybrid classification performance, distinctly surpassing the outcomes achieved by the individual modalities. Moreover, this performance boost was notably superior to conventional classification without employing feature selection. These results suggest a promising potential for our proposed framework in a broader spectrum of neuro-clinical applications. As a culmination of our efforts, we successfully engineered a real-time fNIRS-EEG-based BCI equipped with multiple degrees of freedom, purpose-built for navigation applications. Our outcomes showcased performance metrics that substantially exceeded chance levels across all participants involved in the study.

This award played a pivotal role in fostering inclusivity and providing numerous avenues for under-represented minorities (URMs) to engage in the research endeavors outlined in the proposal. The grant facilitated a range of educational and outreach initiatives that left a lasting impact. One such endeavor involved hosting plenary talks featuring keynote speakers, followed by an informative workshop that delved into the fundamentals of designing and configuring hybrid EEG-fNIRS BCIs. Additionally, an educational event was orchestrated, targeting middle school students with the aim of imparting fundamental knowledge about BCI systems. Beyond these initiatives, the grant outcomes supported the creation of educational resources, which in turn enabled the establishment of a permanent course titled "BME 473/ ELE 573 Brain signal processing and Applications" in the curriculum at URI. This course serves as a testament to the lasting legacy of this grant, offering students a dedicated avenue to explore the multifaceted realm of BCIs.
